title: How would you say John Lennon's vocals for The Beatles changed over the years? - Quora

response.answer_text: Lennon started off trying to sing like his idols, just like McCartney. But whereas McCartney could roar notes “out of the top of his head”, imitating Little Richard, John couldn’t quite hit those same notes, but he could still belt it. Lennon, I’d guess, went more for a Buddy Holly sound with his voice. You can also hear Lonnie Donegan’s high voice and Elvis’s croon in John’s earlier Beatles vocals. I think the main vocal influence for Lennon’s vocals in the early Beatle days is Tony Sheridan. The Beatles, apparently, were in awe of Sheridan when they first started playing with him and his influence, I think, can be heard in John’s vocals in those early days. So, I’d say from the very early days until maybe ‘65 or ’66 John’s voice was very rock and roll with the swagger and depth of Elvis and the higher, nasal qualities of Buddy Holly, Lonnie Donegan, and Tony Sheridan. After The Beatles made their way onto the American charts and invaded American shores, John was introduced to Bob Dylan. I’m not positive, and maybe someone else can clarify this, but I think John had heard Dylan before he met him. John became very interested in Dylan’s writing and you can hear the way John’s songs start to become more personal and poetic in response to this influence. Think Norwegian Wood. John’s voice also seems to shift away from the Elvis-style depth and swagger and more into the nose. His voice becomes a little more honest and has a bit more of a ragged edge to it. Of course, cigarettes, I’m sure, added to this. It’s during this period (Rubber Soul, Revolver) when Lennon’s vocals become really interesting because he really starts to interpret the lyrics with his voice, adding that emotional connection that a lot of people talk about when they talk about Lennon’s vocals. He could go back to that Rock and Roll roar with songs like Yer Blues, but his best moments are when he’s very much himself. For a good example of this shift, listen to something like Please Please Me or Twist and Shout and then listen to Norwegian Wood, Julia, or even his later songs like Mother. I’d suggest listening to Lennon’s demo of a song called Help Me to Help Myself to really hear how honest and pure his voice could be.

response.answer_text: Early Beatles John had to harmonize with Paul and at times with George. Later Beatles he often sung alone. John also let his emotions come out in his singing. Later Beatles we had bitter then disinterested John. John’s voice was always a bit “rough” compared to Paul. He had an edge to it. Paul’s voice was softer. George’s voice was a bit thin and at times weak; maybe a confidence issue.
